answers.answer: Hi,Proteinuria or abnormal amounts of protein in the urine occur when the filters of the kidney, called glomeruli, are damaged. Other conditions that can damage the glomeruli and cause proteinuria include diabetes, hypertension, and other forms of kidney diseases.  This can also lead to cardiovascular diseases.I would recommend that you have another test done and if you have persistent proteinuria, additional tests must be done to evaluate your kidney function.  If you have diabetes, hypertension, or both, the first goal of treatment will be to control your blood glucose and blood pressure. Having a low salt and low protein diet may also help. Take care and keep us posted.

question: I was tested at my OB/GYN yesterday and after doing having my urine tested i was told to tell my general doctor that i have +3 protein count. Can anyone tell what this means and if so what areas of the body would be affected and what i would need to do to help get it normal levels?
title: +3 protein count
